pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Lysozyme</button> is an enzyme present in most body fluids, including mucus, tears, saliva, and sweat. It constitutes an important part of the body’s network of defenses against pathogenic microbes. In this investigation, students will apply egg white, a natural source of lysozyme, to a bacterial culture to observe the antibacterial effect of this enzyme.

pageData.text: How many parents have said to their children, “Don’t pick your nose and eat it”? Is this simply disgusting child behavior or is there a deeper evolutionary explanation? The technical name for booger-eating is mucophagy, but when the habit becomes obsessional, it is known as rhinotillexomania.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Boogers allow the body to remove dust, dirt, and microbes from the air before it enters the lungs. These particles are trapped in mucus, which congeals into boogers, which can be dry or slimy. The hygiene hypothesis suggests that exposure to pathogenic microbes can boost the immune system<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>, which may be why children often eat boogers. However, studies show that because boogers contain potentially harmful microbes, their consumption is not recommended<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>. The booger-eating debate has been difficult to settle. Would you volunteer for a booger-eating research study?

1Li, J.T.C. (20 April 2021). Hygiene hypothesis: Does early germ exposure prevent asthma? Mayo Clinic.
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/childhood-asthma/expert-answers/hygiene-hypothesis/faq-20058102

2Wertheim, H. F. L., van Kleef, M., Vos, M. C., Ott, A., Verbrugh, H. A., & Fokkens, W. (21 June 2016). Nose Picking and Nasal Carriage of Staphylococcus aureus. Infection Control & Hospital Epidemiology,
27(8), 863-867. doi:10.1086/506401 and picking... by Quinn Norton is available under CC BY 2.0 at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/quinn/171572

Microbes are everywhere in our environment. We are constantly in contact with them. Microbes inhabit our skin, upper respiratory passages, oral cavity, and gastrointestinal tract. The vast majority of microbes we encounter cause us no harm but instead are directly or indirectly beneficial. However, some are capable of causing infection and disease. Such microbes are known as <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button>.
The human body has an elaborate defense network to protect against pathogenic microbes. This network is often described in terms of three lines of defense:

1. Physical and chemical barriers keep pathogens from invading the body’s tissues. These barriers are part of the body’s , with which all humans are born. These barriers are nonspecific, meaning they provide general protection against all microbes and are not specific to a particular species or strain.
    2. Physical barriers include:
    • Intact skin and mucous membranes
    • Nasal hairs and eyelashes
    • Cilia of the upper respiratory tract
    • Flushing action of tears, urination, defecation, and vomiting
    Chemical barriers include:
    • , an antibacterial enzyme present in tears, saliva, and other secretions
    • Gastric juice, a highly acidic substance secreted by the stomach lining
    • Low pH and oily secretion (sebum) of the skin

1. when the physical and chemical barriers fail part of our innate immunity. This second line of defense acts against all types of microbes and includes:
    • Inflammation, a localized response to tissue injury
    • Phagocytes, specialized cells that engulf and destroy microbes
    • Fever, an increase in body temperature that inhibits microbial growth

2. targets certain microbes that the body recognizes as foreign. This third line of defense is also known as , because the immune system “learns” from exposure to potentially pathogenic microbes throughout a life span and generates stronger, more rapid responses to previously encountered microbes. Specific resistance involves specialized white blood cells called lymphocytes.

pageData.text: The focus of this investigation will be on <button class='glossary-text'>lysozyme</button> as an important part of the first line of defense. Lysozyme was discovered in 1922 by Dr. Alexander Fleming, who several years later discovered an antibacterial mold from which he derived the antibiotic drug penicillin. Fleming was working in his laboratory while suffering from a cold and decided to apply some of his nasal mucus to a bacterial culture in a Petri dish. Weeks later, he examined the culture and noticed that, although the culture was generally growing well, the area to which he had applied mucus lacked bacterial growth.

As luck would have it, Fleming had applied his nasal mucus to a bacterium that is highly vulnerable to the effects of lysozyme. Fleming named the bacterial species Micrococcus lysodeikticus, later changed to Micrococcus luteus. He suggested that this species, which is nonpathogenic, does not pose a threat to humans because of its susceptibility to lysozyme.

Fleming then discovered lysozyme is present not only in nasal mucus but also in tears, saliva, and most other body fluids. Once Fleming realized that lysozyme could be obtained from tears, he began squeezing lemon juice into his own eyes as well as those of students and laboratory workers to obtain lysozyme for study. Fortunately for those who passed through Dr. Fleming’s laboratory, nonhuman animals also produce lysozyme. In later experiments, Fleming obtained his lysozyme from raw egg whites. We now know that lysozyme is not unique to animals and is present in plants.

Lysozyme attacks <button class='glossary-text'>peptidoglycan</button>, a complex polymer of amino acids and sugars that is an important component of the bacterial cell wall. An intact cell wall allows a bacterium to survive osmotic and mechanical challenges. By weakening the cell wall, lysozyme makes the bacterium much more likely to <button class='glossary-text'>lyse</button>, or burst open. However, not all bacteria are equally susceptible to lysozyme. Gram-negative bacteria in particular are less affected because their cell walls contain much less peptidoglycan than those of Gram-positive bacteria (Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Differences in peptidoglycan in Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Differences in peptidoglycan in Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria

pageData.text: Even among Gram-positive bacteria, not all species are as vulnerable to lysozyme as M. luteus. The structure of peptidoglycan can vary between species, with some being more resistant to the action of lysozyme than others. For example, members of the genus Staphylococcus (such as the pathogen S. aureus) are Gram-positive and are highly resistant to lysozyme. In this investigation, you will use an egg white to examine the effect of lysozyme on a culture of the Gram-positive bacterium M. luteus.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
Refer to your instructions and videos on safe laboratory practices before beginning this investigation.
Isopropyl alcohol is flammable. Keep containers of isopropyl alcohol away from any heat or flame sources.

Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area and all lab equipment with soap and water after completing the investigation.

Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution (one part bleach to nine parts tap water) before starting the investigation. After completing your work, disinfect and discard any used inoculating tools and unneeded cultures. Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution followed by soap and water. Always wear PPE when disinfecting.

Note: Use correct aseptic technique as you are working through this investigation. You may wish to review the Aseptic Technique and Use of Media investigation to refresh your memory. In particular, each time you remove the cap from a tube, the cap should be held, not placed on the work surface. The open mouth of each glass culture tube should be flamed as soon as the cap is removed and immediately before the cap is replaced.Culture Recommendations You will need a fresh broth culture of M. luteus for this investigation to be successful. Using an old culture will result in uneven growth and results that are difficult to interpret.
  • If you have a broth culture of M. luteus that is no more than two weeks old, you may skip the preparation and proceed directly to the activity.
  • If you need to reactivate a lyophilized culture of M. luteus, follow the instructions that came with the culture using proper aseptic technique and incubate until growth is evident in the tryptic soy broth.You may wish to first review the video:

Skip the preparation and proceed directly to the activity.
  • If you have a reactivated culture of M. luteus that is more than two weeks old, carry out all of the preparation steps before proceeding to the activity.
Follow your instructor’s directions on which cultures to keep and which to discard at the end of the investigation.

pageData.text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, test tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.

Retrieve the needed media and, if applicable, lyophilized culture, from storage. If the media have been stored in the refrigerator, allow them to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature.
Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Obtain the liquid paraffin candle from the equipment kit. Light the candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from open containers of isopropyl alcohol.

Mix the contents of the reactivated or older M. luteus culture by tapping the tube or rolling it between your palms. Aseptically transfer a loop of broth to a fresh tube of tryptic soy broth labeled M. luteus.
Place the loop in the disposal jar; let it sit for at least 30 minutes, then discard the loop in the garbage.
Extinguish the candle, and empty the alcohol from the disposal jar as described in the Disposal and Cleanup section. Keep the jar for later use.

Incubate the inoculated broth tube upright in the rack with its cap slightly loose. (This permits air to enter the tube while keeping contaminants out, because M. luteus requires oxygen for growth.) M. luteus grows best at approximately 25° C (77° F).
Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution, remove your PPE, and wash your hands thoroughly.
Allow between 2 and 4 days of incubation for the broth to become turbid (cloudy) and yellowish in color. Do not proceed until the culture is growing well, as evidenced by heavy turbidity.

Both Micrococcus luteus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are non-motile and their growth will be along the bottom of the tube. You can gently jostle the tube a bit to see if the growth at bottom of the tube swirls. If you see a good swirl of growth at the bottom then your culture should be ready to proceed to the next step.
The Escherichia coli and Serratia marcescens are both motile and their growth should be throughout the culture medium so they will appear turbid though they will also have more growth along the bottom of the tube.
Wait until your culture is turbid before proceeding to Activity 2. Micrococcus luteus is fastidious and grows slowly at suboptimal conditions. If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to become significantly turbid.

In Activity 1, you will inoculate a nutrient agar plate with M. luteus and place on the medium two filter paper disks - one dipped in egg white as a source of and one sterile control disk. You will then incubate the plates over 96 hours and observe the effects of lysozyme on M. luteus growth.

pageData.text: Wash your hands, put on your PPE, disinfect the work area, prepare the disposal jar of alcohol, and light the candle (a safe distance from the alcohol).
Prepare the lysozyme sample.

Disinfect the inside of the plastic cup by wiping it with a paper towel moistened with isopropyl alcohol and letting it sit for about 2 minutes. Then wipe the inside of the cup again with a dry paper towel to remove any remaining alcohol.

Disinfect the outside of the eggshell carefully with a paper towel moistenedwith isopropyl alcohol. Allow the egg to sit for about 2 minutes, then wipe it with a dry paper towel to remove any residual alcohol.

text: 1. Break the egg gently into the plastic cup, taking care not to break the yolk.

pageData.text: Obtain a tryptic soy agar plate, invert it, and label one side of the Petri dish “egg” and the other “control” as shown in Figure 2.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Diagram of a large circle, representing the nutrient agar plate. Inside the circle are two smaller circles, representing the egg disk and the blank control disk. They are spaced at equal distances from one another and from the side of the Petri dish.

pageData.text: Mix the M. luteus culture well by tightly capping the tube and tapping it or rolling it gently between your hands. Then use the sterile swab to obtain broth from the tube.

Note: Part of correct aseptic technique is avoiding removal of the lid from a Petri dish. Open the lid just enough to insert and move the swab, and use the lid as a shield to keep dust off the agar surface. Close the lid as soon as you are finished.

Note: It is important that all the cells are in suspension. If there is a mass of cells (sediment) at the bottom of the tube, it may be necessary to gently invert the tube to ensure the cells are in suspension. Once your cells are in suspension, your culture should appear turbid.
Inoculate the plate by gently pulling the swab across the entire surface of the agar in a very tight back-and-forth, zigzag pattern.

Turn the plate approximately 90°, and without dipping the swab back into the M. luteus culture tube, pull the swab again over the entire surface of the agar in a very tight back-and-forth, zigzag pattern. Try not to miss any of the agar surface.

Repeat Step 7 two more times until you have swabbed the entire surface of the agar plate a total of four times. Place the swab in the disposal jar. Unless otherwise instructed, keep your M. luteus broth culture for later use.
Let the plate sit with the lid on and the agar side facing up.

Sterilize your forceps by dipping them into the jar of isopropyl alcohol, tapping them gently on the rim to remove excess alcohol, and then lighting the remaining alcohol on the forceps with the candle and allowing it to burn off while holding the forceps away from your body. Wait at least 15–20 seconds for the forceps to cool.
Using the forceps, obtain one sterile paper disk and place it in the egg white, allowing it to become completely saturated. Remove the disk, allowing excess egg white to drip into the cup.

Place the egg white disk on the surface of the agar in the center of the “egg” half (see Figure 2), taking care not to drip any extra egg white on the agar. Press very gently with the forceps to ensure that the disk is seated firmly on the agar. Do not press too hard, or you will break the surface of the agar.
Dip the forceps in the alcohol, and sterilize them in the candle flame.

Pick up a blank, sterile paper control disk, and place it on the surface of the agar in the center of the “control” half (see Figure 2). Press very gently with the forceps to ensure that the disk is firmly seated on the agar.
Dip the forceps in the alcohol, and sterilize them in the candle flame.
Clean your work area as directed in the Disposal and Cleanup section.

After approximately 24 hours of incubation, examine your plate with the lid on. Do not remove the lid of the Petri dish during any observations, because this may result in contamination. First, look for signs of bacterial growth. M. luteus produces a yellow pigment. As the culture grows, the surface of the agar should appear increasingly yellowish and opaque. Do not be alarmed if little or no growth is evident at 24 hours; M. luteus tends to grow slowly. As the culture continues to grow, the egg white disk should be noticeably surrounded by a transparent area where bacteria were unable to grow due to the effects of . Check the control disk to see if it is surrounded by a clear zone. There should be no clear zone surrounding the control disk.

Prepare to photograph your plate. Avoid use of the flash, which will simply be reflected from the lid. Do not remove the lid of the Petri dish to take photos. You may need to experiment with lighting conditions and camera angles to get the best pictures in your work space.
Observe and photograph the plate again at approximately 48, 72, and 96 hours, noting the presence of clear zones around either of the disks.
Note: Micrococcus luteus is fastidious and grows slowly at suboptimal conditions. If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to show significant growth.
Dispose of the used egg in the garbage. Wash the plastic cup with soap and water, and return it to the equipment set.

To dispose of used inoculating tools (loops and/or swabs), let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes; then while wearing PPE, pour the alcohol down the drain while the faucet is running and discard the tools wrapped in an opaque plastic bag in the garbage. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol.
Keep your broth culture of M. luteus unless otherwise directed by your instructor.

To dispose of any cultures that will not be needed later, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a lidded plastic container large enough to hold all the cultures with a 10% bleach solution. While holding each tube or plate submerged in the bleach solution, open the tube or plate. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.

Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected tubes and plates in an opaque plastic bag, and discard it in the garbage.
After working with microbes, be sure to disinfect the work space with a 10% bleach solution and then clean it with soap and water. Wear PPE when carrying out the disinfection.
